title.narrative: Technical Assistance To The Municipal Government Of San Nicolás De Los Garza In The Consolidation Of A City Vision For Urban And Territorial Development Of The Municipality, Aligned With The 2030 Agenda And The New Urban Agenda

description.narrative:
Background
In August 2018, the municipality of San Nicolás de los Garza and UN-Habitat initiated informative talks on the metropolitan workshop about the extended CPI from agglomeration of the city Monterrey. On November 8, 2018, UN-Habitat received a letter of expression of interest from Mr. Oswaldo Cervantes Rodríguez, the Technical Secretary of the office of the presidency of San Nicolás de los Garza, stating an interest in exploring areas of opportunity with UN-Habitat to establish a possible partnership framework.
After various conversations, the municipality has shown its interest in receiving technical assistance from UN-Habitat to develop a Vision Document that can serve as a main input for developing the Municipal Urban Development Program and updating its regulations on urban and ecological development and priority issues in administration.
Following up on this request, UN-Habitat presents a technical proposal through this document. To formalize this technical collaboration, by mutual agreement between the parties, we will proceed with the signing of a Contribution Agreement (CA). Its objectives and scope will be included in Technical Annex of the CA.
The signature of the CA will be subject to legal opinions from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.[1]
Justification
The municipality of San Nicolás de los Garza is located in the center-western region of the state of Nuevo León; northern Mexico. It is one of the main municipalities in Monterrey conurbation, contributing to urban agglomeration of Monterrey along with its other municipalities such as Apodaca, Guadalupe, Monterrey, General Escobedo, Santa Catarina, Juárez, Garcia, San Pedro Garza García, Cadereyta de Jiménez, General Zuazua, Santiago, Salinas Victoria, Ciénegas de Flores, Pesquería and El Carmen.
The urban agglomeration of Monterrey in northeastern Mexico, in the state of Nuevo León, is the second largest urban area in Mexico with an area of 784 km2 including 16 municipalities. Due to its strategic location, it has positioned itself as the most important urban center in northern Mexico, with an outstanding dynamic in business, industry and education.
In 2015, the urban area of San Nicolás de los Garza was 58.6 km², which is equivalent to 7.5% of the urban area of the agglomeration of Monterrey and a population of 430,143 inhabitants[2].
The urbanization index of San Nicolás is 100% and is above the average of the agglomeration rate (98.2%). However, the average annual growth rates between 2000-2015 of population (-1.0%) and housing (0.4%) are well below the values presented by the agglomeration rates (2.1% and 3.3%, respectively). This trend of low population growth in the municipality is expected to continue. It is estimated that for the 2015-2030 period the growth rate will be higher than the current rate of 1.0% annual average. By 2030, according to projections of the National Population Council, the population will be of 499,418 inhabitants (CONAPO, 2015).
As explained in the CPI Report, the close relationship between San Nicolás de los Garza and the municipalities of the urban agglomeration, its economic dynamics, decreasing demographic dynamism and the exhaustion of urbanizable land, stand out as the main contextual elements that should be considered in interpreting the results of the CPI and the agglomeration.
The economically active population (PEA) of the municipality is 50.8%, 69.3% of the employed population is concentrated in the tertiary sector, 28% is in the secondary sector and less than 1% in the primary sector (table 4).
Table 1. Situation statistics of San Nicolás de los Garza.
Source: CPI, ONU-Habitat (2018) a partir de INEGI (2000), INEGI (2010a), INEGI (2009), INEGI (2010b), INEGI (2010c), INEGI (2014) CONAPO (2015), INEGI (2015).
As exhaustion of urbanizable land in the municipality restricts its possibilities for future expansion the reuse of land through densification policies is of relevance to this issue (City of Monterrey, 2013). On the other hand, real estate investment in unconsolidated land has facilitated a disorderly and unsustainable expansion, lacking an adequate territorial and ecological planning strategy, which in turn has led to environmental problems.
The City Prosperity Index of the Municipality of San Nicolás de los Garza is 58.96/100, classified as moderately weak, which implies that it might be important to strengthen public policies in areas with less favorable results and, at the same time, to consolidate the areas with the best results. This value is considerably higher than 53.80/100, which is the value of the urban agglomeration of Monterrey, delimited from processes and spatial analysis of remote sensing with satellite images and also higher than the national average of the basic CPI (53.74/100).
Figure 1. Results by dimension of the Basic CPI for San Nicolás de los Garza.
Source: CPI, UN-Habitat (2018).
The results of the CPI indicate that the city has the comparative advantages in the dimensions of ‘Quality of Life’ and ‘Equity and Social Inclusion’ where the city has obtained relatively solid results; but at the same time, its challenges must be addressed as well, particularly in the dimensions of Urban Governance and Legislation and Environmental Sustainability, where it shows the lowest values.
Likewise, an imbalance is observed in the results of the CPI dimensions. Therefore, there are some dimensions that contribute to the development of the municipality, but others are conditioning factors for its prosperity and well-being.
The Municipal Government of San Nicolás de los Garza has a "Municipal Development Plan 2018-2021", which has a long-term vision for achievement of the 2030 Agenda and in coherence with the 2030 Strategic Plan for the State of Nuevo León. This municipal plan is structured through three guiding axes. The first one is sustainable territorial and urban development, which seeks, among others, to consolidate the municipality as an intelligent city, where an orderly planning is promoted in order to orient the processes and policies towards urban growth, housing, equipment and infrastructure, land uses and urban mobility.
The municipal government, through its Technical Secretariat and the Directorate of Strategic Projects, seeks to strengthen strategic planning in terms of urban and territorial development by preparing and updating the different urban planning instruments and promoting citizen participation.
Currently, the updating its Municipal Urban Development Program (MUPD) is in progress with a vision to 2040, and an Urban Identity Project 2019-2021 formulation is anticipated through update of regulations. The MUPD is a binding technical-legal instrument that will determine where and how the city will develop in the coming decades. Likewise, it will enable the city to have a development plan based on its interaction with two other municipalities of Guadalupe and Apodaca.
In this context, a unique opportunity is identified for the municipality to have a long-term City Vision aligned with the fundamental principles of ‘leave no one and no place behind’. These principles dominate the sustainable development mentioned in the global agreements and international and national agendas such as the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, the New Urban Agenda, the Paris Agreement, the Sendai Framework, the National Development Plan and the 2030 Strategic Plan of Nuevo León, the Municipal Development Plan of San Nicolás, among others. The principles are also to be embodied in the planning instruments that are to be updated.
Under this collaboration, the establishment of an international cooperation framework is envisaged, seeking to develop an innovative urban planning strategy for the city, with a development vision agreed by its citizens. A territorial approach and the purpose of leading urban development are also included, with the collaboration of the private, public, and social sectors for the collective actions and a long-term vision.
Based on the above, it is possible to point out that San Nicolás is at a critical period to strengthen its planning based on the existing evidence through a holistic and integrated approach that would eventually lead to a more prosperous future with a better quality of life for its inhabitants.
1. [1] According to the Collaboration Agreement Framework 2014-2019 between the Government of the United Mexican States and the United Nations Human Settlements Programme (UN-Habitat).
[2] The methodology of the CPI uses the concept of "urban agglomeration" to interpret and delimit the territory from a socio-spatial analysis, in which technical processes of geomatics are considered to provide elements of statistical support to calculate the index, improving the comparability of the Mexican cities with those analyzed in the Atlas of Urban Expansion (Lincoln Institute of Land Policy, 2012).

title.narrative: San Nicolás de los Garza adopts and incorporates in its urban and territorial planning instruments, a vision for the future, agreed between multiple actors and aligned with the principles of the 2030 Agenda and the New Urban Agenda, as well as strategies aimed at strengthening the different dimensions of urban prosperity at the local level, positioning itself as a reference in the implementation of global agendas in Mexico.

title.narrative: San Nicolás de los Garza strengthens its capacities for urban and territorial planning, and adopts a plan for the implementation of strategic actions and projects based on evidence, which allows it to guide its institutional efforts to become a compact, sustainable, inclusive and resilient city that generates shared prosperity for all its inhabitants.
